title: Can scientists locate local clumps of dark matter by measuring gravitational effects, and if not, why not? - Quora

response.answer_text: Locally? Dark matter doesn't really "clump", it's just wafting around the place. As for local effects you got to remember that gravity is a very weak force. Very difficult to measure in great detail except at cosmic scales. Think about it. If a 500 tonne train drives by do you feel it's gravity? Nope. In fact you'd need a pretty damn sensitive instrument to pick it up at all. I'm not sure even a laser inferometer is up to the task. So detecting a bit of dark matter in your area would be very difficult.
There is no such thing as clumps of dark matter. Dark matter is like an ocean of water with a constant pressure. It can't make objects just like water can't.
There are no “local clumps” of dark matter. It does not seem to form structures smaller than about 600 light years across, according to a British-Australian survey.
